heading: Births
txt: Mallory Hagan, Miss America 2013

entities.title: Mallory Hagan
entities.description: Mallory Hytes Hagan is an American politician and former beauty queen who won Miss America 2013 as Miss New York 2012. She moved to New York in 2008 after her first year of college at Auburn University. Prior to winning Miss America, Hagan was also Miss Brooklyn 2010, Miss Manhattan 2011, Miss New York City 2012 and a two-time Miss New York first runner-up. When living in Alabama, Hagan had been r

entities.title: Miss America 2013
entities.description: Miss America 2013, the 86th Miss America pageant, was held at the PH Live at Planet Hollywood Resort & Casino on the Las Vegas Strip in Paradise, Nevada on Saturday, January 12, 2013. It was the last one to take place in Las Vegas. "America's Choice" winner, Alexis Wineman was the pageant's first autistic contestant. The 2013 winner Mallory Hagan was crowned by Miss America 2012 Laura Kaeppeler. H

heading: Births
txt: Liis Koger, Estonian painter and poet

entities.title: Liis Koger
entities.description: Liis Koger is an Estonian painter and poet based in Tallinn.

heading: Births
txt: Jeff Schlupp, German footballer

entities.title: Jeff Schlupp
entities.description:
Jeffrey Schlupp is a professional footballer who plays for Premier League club Crystal Palace and the Ghana national team as a left back or winger. Born in Germany, he represents Ghana at the international level.
Schlupp started his career as a striker.

heading: Births
txt: Reed Alexander, American actor

entities.title: Reed Alexander
entities.description: Reed Alexander is an American journalist, author, and former actor from Boca Raton, Florida. He is best known for his role as Nevel Papperman in Nickelodeon's iCarly.

heading: Births
txt: Bartosz Kapustka, Polish footballer

entities.title: Bartosz Kapustka
entities.description: Bartosz Kapustka is a Polish professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for Ekstraklasa club Legia Warsaw.

heading: Births
txt: Finn Wolfhard, Canadian actor and musician

entities.title: Finn Wolfhard
entities.description: Finn Wolfhard is a Canadian actor, musician, screenwriter, and director.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ming Yuan Di, ruler of Northern Wei (b. 392)

entities.title: Emperor Mingyuan of Northern Wei
entities.description: Emperor Mingyuan of Northern Wei ( 魏明元帝), Chinese name Tuoba Si (拓拔嗣), Xianbei name Mumo (木末), was an emperor of the Xianbei dynasty Northern Wei. He was the oldest son of the founding emperor Emperor Daowu. During his reign, Northern Wei's territory did not expand as much as it did under either his father's reign or the reign of his son Emperor Taiwu, but he helped the state stabilize over northe

entities.title: Northern Wei
entities.description: The Northern Wei, also known as the Tuoba Wei (拓跋魏), Later Wei (後魏), was a dynasty founded by the Tuoba (Tabgach) clan of the Xianbei, which ruled northern China from 386 to 534 AD, during the period of the Northern and Southern dynasties. Described as "part of an era of political turbulence and intense social and cultural change", the Northern Wei dynasty is particularly noted for unifying northe

heading: Deaths
txt: Huneric, Vandal king

entities.title: Huneric
entities.description: Huneric, Hunneric or Honeric was King of the Vandal Kingdom (477–484) and the oldest son of Genseric. He abandoned the imperial politics of his father and concentrated mainly on internal affairs. He was married to Eudocia, daughter of western Roman Emperor Valentinian III (419–455) and Licinia Eudoxia. The couple had one child, a son named Hilderic.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gabriel of Beth Qustan, bishop and saint (b. 594)

entities.title: Gabriel of Beth Qustan
entities.description: Saint Gabriel of Beth Qustan, also known as Saint Gabriel of Qartmin, was the Bishop of Tur Abdin until his death in 648. He is venerated as a saint in the Oriental Orthodox Church and his feast day is 23 December.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dagobert II, Frankish king (probable; b. 650)

entities.title: Dagobert II
entities.description: Dagobert II was the Merovingian king of the Franks ruling in Austrasia from 675 or 676 until his death. He is one of the more obscure Merovingians. He has been considered a martyr since at least the ninth century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gaubald, Frankish bishop (b. 700)

entities.title: Gaubald
entities.description: Gaubald was the first bishop of Regensburg after the foundation of the diocese of Regensburg. He has been beatified. His name is also spelled Gawibald, Geupald or Gaibald.

heading: Deaths
txt: Solomon II, bishop of Constance

entities.title: Solomon II (bishop of Constance)
entities.description: Solomon II was the Bishop of Constance from 875 until his death. He was a relative of his predecessor and namesake Solomon I and stood in the middle of an "episcopal dynasty." He was commended for his life when the Annales Fuldenses record his death. He was succeeded by his own namesake and another relative, Solomon III.

entities.title: Bishopric of Constance
entities.description: The Prince-Bishopric of Constance, was a small ecclesiastical principality of the Holy Roman Empire from the mid–12th century until its secularisation in 1802–1803. In his dual capacity as prince and as bishop, the prince-bishop was also in charge of the considerably larger Roman Catholic Diocese of Konstanz, which existed from about 585 until its dissolution in 1821. It belonged to the ecclesiast

heading: Deaths
txt: Naum of Preslav, Bulgarian missionary and scholar

entities.title: Saint Naum
entities.description: Saint Naum, also known as Naum of Ohrid or Naum of Preslav was a medieval Bulgarian writer, enlightener, one of the seven Apostles of the First Bulgarian Empire and missionary among the Slavs. He was among the disciples of Saints Cyril and Methodius and is associated with the creation of the Glagolitic and Cyrillic script. Naum was among the founders of the Pliska Literary School. Afterwards Naum

heading: Deaths
txt: Conrad I, king of East Francia (b. 890)

entities.title: Conrad I of Germany
entities.description: Conrad I, called the Younger, was the king of East Francia from 911 to 918. He was the first king not of the Carolingian dynasty, the first to be elected by the nobility and the first to be anointed. He was chosen as the king by the rulers of the East Frankish stem duchies after the death of young king Louis the Child. Ethnically Frankish, prior to this election he had ruled the Duchy of Franconia

entities.title: East Francia
entities.description: East Francia or the Kingdom of the East Franks was a successor state of Charlemagne's empire ruled by the Carolingian dynasty until 911. It was created through the Treaty of Verdun (843) which divided the former empire into three kingdoms.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ar-Radi, Abbasid caliph (b. 909)

entities.title: Ar-Radi
entities.description: Abu'l-Abbas Ahmad (Muhammad) ibn Ja'far al-Muqtadir, usually simply known by his regnal name al-Radi bi'llah, was the twentieth Caliph of the Abbasid Caliphate, reigning from 934 to his death. He died on 23 December 940 at the age of 31. His reign marked the end of the caliph's political power and the rise of military strongmen, who competed for the title of amir al-umara.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ugo Ventimiglia, Italian cardinal

entities.title: Ugo Ventimiglia
entities.description: Ugo Ventimiglia was an Italian cardinal. His name is listed also as Ottone. He was born in Ventimiglia. He was created Cardinal-Bishop of Palestrina by Pope Alexander III in the consistory celebrated in Sens in 1164. Several catalogs of the bishops of Palestrina do not mention him because he does not appear among signatories of any papal bulls issued during his cardinalate.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thorlak, patron saint of Iceland (b. 1133)

entities.title: Saint Thorlak
entities.description: Thorlak Thorhallsson is the patron saint of Iceland. He was bishop of Skálholt from 1178 until his death. Thorlak's relics were translated to the cathedral of Skalholt in 1198, not long after his successor as bishop, Páll Jónsson, announced at the Althing that vows could be made to Thorlak. His status as a saint did not receive official recognition from the Catholic Church until 14 January 1984, w

heading: Deaths
txt: Berengaria of Navarre, queen of England (b. 1165)

entities.title: Berengaria of Navarre
entities.description: Berengaria of Navarre was queen of England as the wife of Richard I of England. She was the eldest daughter of Sancho VI of Navarre and Sancha of Castile. As is the case with many of the medieval English queens, relatively little is known of her life.

heading: Deaths
txt: Matilda of Habsburg, duchess regent of Bavaria  (b. 1253)

entities.title: Matilda of Habsburg
entities.description: Matilda of Habsburg or Melchilde was, by marriage, a duchess of Bavaria. She was regent of Bavaria in the minority of her son, Rudolf I.

heading: Deaths
txt: Beatrice of Bourbon, Queen of Bohemia (b. 1320)

entities.title: Beatrice of Bourbon, Queen of Bohemia
entities.description: Beatrice of Bourbon was a French noblewoman. A member of the House of Bourbon, she was by marriage Queen of Bohemia and Countess of Luxembourg.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Preljubović, ruler of Epirus

entities.title: Thomas Preljubović
entities.description: Thomas Preljubović was ruler of the Despotate of Epirus in Ioannina from 1366 to his death on December 23, 1384. He also held the title of Albanian-slayer after receiving aid from the Ottoman Empire to capture Ioannina from Albanian ruler of the Despotate of Arta, Gjin Bua Shpata, after failing to do so independently. The Albanian Slayer (Ἀλβανοκτόνος).

heading: Deaths
txt: Isabella of Castile, duchess of York (b. 1355)

entities.title: Isabella of Castile, Duchess of York
entities.description: Isabella of Castile, Duchess of York was the daughter of King Peter and his mistress María de Padilla. She accompanied her elder sister, Constance, to England after Constance's marriage to John of Gaunt, 1st Duke of Lancaster, and married Gaunt's younger brother, Edmund of Langley, 1st Duke of York.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicholas Udall, English cleric, playwright, and educator (b. 1504)

entities.title: Nicholas Udall
entities.description: Nicholas Udall was an English playwright, cleric, schoolmaster, the author of Ralph Roister Doister, generally regarded as the first comedy written in the English language.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger Ascham, English scholar and academic (b. 1515)

entities.title: Roger Ascham
entities.description: Roger Ascham was an English scholar and didactic writer, famous for his prose style, his promotion of the vernacular, and his theories of education. He served in the administrations of Edward VI, Mary I, and Elizabeth I, having earlier acted as Elizabeth's tutor in Greek and Latin between 1548 and 1550.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Sylvan, German theologian (executed; date of birth unknown)

entities.title: Johann Sylvan
entities.description: Johann Sylvan was a Reformed German theologian who was executed for his heretical Antitrinitarian beliefs.

heading: Deaths
txt: Akiyama Nobutomo, Japanese samurai (b. 1531)

entities.title: Akiyama Nobutomo
entities.description: Akiyama Nobutomo  was a samurai during the Sengoku period in Japan. He is known as one of the "Twenty-Four Generals of Takeda Shingen". Nobutomo also served under Shingen's son, Takeda Katsuyori.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry I, duke of Guise (b. 1550)

entities.title: Henry I, Duke of Guise
entities.description: Henry I, Prince of Joinville, Duke of Guise, Count of Eu, sometimes called Le Balafré (Scarface), was the eldest son of Francis, Duke of Guise, and Anna d'Este. His maternal grandparents were Ercole II d'Este, Duke of Ferrara, and Renée of France. Through his maternal grandfather, he was a descendant of Lucrezia Borgia and Pope Alexander VI.

heading: Deaths
txt: Michael Drayton, English poet and playwright (b. 1563)

entities.title: Michael Drayton
entities.description: Michael Drayton was an English poet who came to prominence in the Elizabethan era.

heading: Deaths
txt: Barbara Longhi, Italian painter (b. 1552)

entities.title: Barbara Longhi
entities.description: Barbara Longhi was an Italian painter. She was much admired in her lifetime as a portraitist, although most of her portraits are now lost or unattributed. Her work, such as her many Madonna and Child paintings, earned her a fine reputation as an artist.

heading: Deaths
txt: François Maynard, French poet and academic (b. 1582)

entities.title: François Maynard
entities.description: François Maynard, sometimes seen as "de Maynard" was a French poet who spent much of his life in Toulouse.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Cotton, English minister and theologian (b. 1585)

entities.title: John Cotton (minister)
entities.description: John Cotton was a clergyman in England and the American colonies and was considered the preeminent minister and theologian of the Massachusetts Bay Colony. He studied for five years at Trinity College, Cambridge, and another nine at Emmanuel College, Cambridge. He had already built a reputation as a scholar and outstanding preacher when he accepted the position of minister at St. Botolph's Church,

heading: Deaths
txt: Caesar, duc de Choiseul, French general and diplomat (b. 1602)

entities.title: Caesar, duc de Choiseul
entities.description: César, duc de Choiseul, comte du Plessis-Braslin was a Marshal of France and French diplomat, generally known for the best part of his life as the maréchal (marshal) du Plessis-Braslin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Varignon, French mathematician and academic (b. 1654)

entities.title: Pierre Varignon
entities.description: Pierre Varignon was a French mathematician. He was educated at the Jesuit College and the University of Caen, where he received his M.A. in 1682. He took Holy Orders the following year.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alastair Ruadh MacDonnell, Scottish spy (b. 1725)

entities.title: Alastair Ruadh MacDonnell
entities.description: Alastair MacDonell of Glengarry, also known as Alasdair Ruadh MacDomhnaill, was the 13th chief of Clan MacDonell of Glengarry. Brought up as a Catholic and largely educated in France, he was arrested in November 1745 on his way to join the 1745 Jacobite Rising.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antoine François Prévost, French novelist and translator (b. 1697)

entities.title: Antoine François Prévost
entities.description: Antoine François Prévost d'Exiles, usually known simply as the Abbé Prévost, was a French author and novelist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marie-Marguerite d'Youville, Canadian nun and saint, founded Grey Nuns (b. 1701)

entities.title: Marie-Marguerite d'Youville
entities.description: Marguerite d'Youville was a French Canadian widow who founded the Order of Sisters of Charity of Montreal, commonly known as the Grey Nuns of Montreal. She was canonized by Pope John Paul II of the Roman Catholic Church in 1990, the first native-born Canadian to be declared a saint.

entities.title: Grey Nuns
entities.description: The Sisters of Charity of Montreal, formerly called The Sisters of Charity of the Hôpital Général of Montreal and more commonly known as the Grey Nuns of Montreal, is a Canadian religious institute of Roman Catholic religious sisters, founded in 1737 by Saint Marguerite d'Youville, a young widow.

heading: Deaths
txt: Augustus Hervey, 3rd Earl of Bristol, English admiral and politician, Chief Secretary for Ireland (b. 1724)

entities.title: Augustus Hervey, 3rd Earl of Bristol
entities.description: Admiral Augustus John Hervey, 3rd Earl of Bristol, PC was a Royal Navy officer and politician. He commanded the sixth-rate HMS Phoenix at the Battle of Minorca in May 1756 as well as the third-rate HMS Dragon at the Capture of Belle Île in June 1761, the Invasion of Martinique in January 1762 and the Battle of Havana in June 1762 during the Seven Years' War. He went on to be Chief Secretary for Ir

entities.title: Chief Secretary for Ireland
entities.description: The Chief Secretary for Ireland was a key political office in the British administration in Ireland. Nominally subordinate to the Lord Lieutenant, and officially the "Chief Secretary to the Lord Lieutenant", from the early 19th century until the end of British rule he was effectively the government minister with responsibility for governing Ireland, roughly equivalent to the role of a Secretary of

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles-Michel de l'Épée, French priest and educator (b. 1712)

entities.title: Charles-Michel de l'Épée
entities.description: The Abbé Charles-Michel de l'Épée was a philanthropic educator of 18th-century France who has become known as the "Father of the Deaf".

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Clinton, English general and politician (b. 1730)

entities.title: Henry Clinton (British Army officer, born 1730)
entities.description: General Sir Henry Clinton, KB was a British army officer and politician who sat in the House of Commons between 1772 and 1795. He is best known for his service as a general during the American War of Independence. First arriving in Boston in May 1775, from 1778 to 1782 he was the British Commander-in-Chief in North America. In addition to his military service, due to the influence of his cousin He

heading: Deaths
txt: Pehr Osbeck, Swedish explorer and author (b. 1723)

entities.title: Pehr Osbeck
entities.description: Pehr Osbeck was a Swedish explorer, naturalist and an apostle of Carl Linnaeus. He was born in the parish of Hålanda on Västergötland and studied at Uppsala with Carolus Linnaeus.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Robert Malthus, English economist and demographer (b. 1766)

entities.title: Thomas Robert Malthus
entities.description: Thomas Robert Malthus was an English cleric, scholar and influential economist in the fields of political economy and demography.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Chisum, American businessman and poker player (b. 1824)

entities.title: John Chisum
entities.description: John Simpson Chisum was a wealthy cattle baron in the American West in the mid-to-late 19th century. He was born in Hardeman County, Tennessee, and moved with his family to the Republic of Texas in 1837, later finding work as a building contractor. He also served as county clerk in Lamar County. He was of Scottish, English, and Welsh descent.

heading: Deaths
txt: Constance Naden, English poet and philosopher (b. 1858)

entities.title: Constance Naden
entities.description: Constance Caroline Woodhill Naden was an English writer, poet and philosopher. She studied, wrote and lectured on philosophy and science, alongside publishing two volumes of poetry. Several collected works were published following her death at the young age of 31. In her honour, Robert Lewins established the Constance Naden Medal and had a bust of her installed at Mason Science College. William Ew

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick Tracy Dent, Brigadier General in the Regular United States Army, brother in law to President Ulysses S. Grant.

entities.title: Frederick Tracy Dent
entities.description: Frederick Tracy Dent was an American general.

entities.title: Ulysses S. Grant
entities.description: Ulysses S. Grant was an American military leader who served as the 18th president of the United States from 1869 to 1877. As president, Grant was an effective civil rights executive who created the Justice Department and worked with the Radical Republicans during Reconstruction to protect African Americans. As Commanding General, he led the Union Army to victory in the American Civil War in 1865 a

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick Temple, English archbishop and academic (b. 1821)

entities.title: Frederick Temple
entities.description: Frederick Temple was an English academic, teacher and churchman, who served as Bishop of Exeter (1869-1885), Bishop of London (1885-1896) and Archbishop of Canterbury (1896-1902).

heading: Deaths
txt: Mdungazwe Ngungunyane Nxumalo, last emperor of the Gaza Empire (b. c.1850)

entities.title: Gungunhana
entities.description: Ngungunyane, also known as Mdungazwe Ngungunyane Nxumalo, N'gungunhana, or Gungunhana Reinaldo Frederico Gungunhana, was a tribal king and vassal of the Portuguese Empire, who rebelled, was defeated by General Joaquim Mouzinho de Albuquerque and lived out the rest of his life in exile, first in Lisbon, but later on the island of Terceira, in the Azores.

entities.title: Gaza Empire
entities.description: The Gaza Empire (1824–1895) was an African empire established by general Soshangane and was located in southeastern Africa in the area of southern Mozambique and southeastern Zimbabwe. The Gaza Empire, at its height in the 1860s, covered all of Mozambique between the Zambezi and Limpopo rivers, known as Gazaland.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Schoetensack, German anthropologist and academic (b. 1850)

entities.title: Otto Schoetensack
entities.description: Otto Karl Friedrich Schoetensack was a German industrialist and later professor of anthropology, having retired from the chemical firm which he had founded. During a 1908 archeological dig, he oversaw the worker Daniel Hartmann who found the lower jaw of a hominid, the oldest human fossil then known, which Schoetensack later described formally as Homo heidelbergensis.

heading: Deaths
txt: Swami Shraddhanand, Indian monk, missionary, and educator (b. 1856)

entities.title: Swami Shraddhanand
entities.description: Swami Shraddhanand, also known as Mahatma Munshi Ram Vij, was an Indian Independence activist and an Arya Samaj sannyasi who propagated the teachings of Dayananda Saraswati. This included the establishment of educational institutions, like the Gurukul Kangri University, and played a key role on the Sangathan and the Shuddhi (purification), a Hindu reform movement in the 1920s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mustafa Fehmi Kubilay, Turkish lieutenant and educator (b. 1906)

entities.title: Mustafa Fehmi Kubilay
entities.description: Mustafa Fehmi Kubilay was a Turkish teacher and a lieutenant in the Turkish army. He is considered a "Martyr of the Revolution" in Turkey.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wilson Bentley, American meteorologist and photographer (b. 1865)

entities.title: Wilson Bentley
entities.description: Wilson Alwyn Bentley, also known as Snowflake Bentley, was an American meteorologist and photographer, who was the first known person to take detailed photographs of snowflakes and record their features. He perfected a process of catching flakes on black velvet in such a way that their images could be captured before they either melted or sublimated.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anthony Fokker, Indonesia-born Dutch pilot and engineer, designed the Fokker Dr.I and Fokker D.VII (b. 1890)

entities.title: Anthony Fokker
entities.description: Anton Herman Gerard "Anthony" Fokker was a Dutch aviation pioneer, aviation entrepreneur, aircraft designer, and aircraft manufacturer. He is most famous for the fighter aircraft he produced in Germany during the First World War such as the Eindecker monoplanes, the Dr.1 triplane and the D.VII biplane.

entities.title: Fokker Dr.I
entities.description: The Fokker Dr.I, often known simply as the Fokker Triplane, was a World War I fighter aircraft built by Fokker-Flugzeugwerke. The Dr.I saw widespread service in the spring of 1918. It became famous as the aircraft in which Manfred von Richthofen gained his last 19 victories, and in which he was killed on 21 April 1918.

entities.title: Fokker D.VII
entities.description: The Fokker D.VII was a German World War I fighter aircraft designed by Reinhold Platz of the Fokker-Flugzeugwerke. Germany produced around 3,300 D.VII aircraft in the second half of 1918. In service with the Luftstreitkräfte, the D.VII quickly proved itself to be a formidable aircraft. The Armistice ending the war specifically required, as the fourth clause of the "Clauses Relating to the Western

heading: Deaths
txt: John A. Sampson, American gynecologist and academic (b. 1873)

entities.title: John A. Sampson
entities.description: John Albertson Sampson was a gynecologist who studied endometriosis.

heading: Deaths
txt: Akira Mutō, Japanese general (b. 1883)

entities.title: Akira Mutō
entities.description: Akira Mutō   was a general in the Imperial Japanese Army during World War II. He was convicted of war crimes and sentenced to death by hanging.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hideki Tojo, Japanese general and politician, 40th Prime Minister of Japan (b. 1884)

entities.title: Prime Minister of Japan
entities.description: The prime minister of Japan  is head of the government of Japan, the chief executive of the National Cabinet and the commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Japan; he is appointed by the emperor of Japan after being designated by the National Diet and must enjoy the confidence of the House of Representatives to remain in office. He is the head of the Cabinet and appoints and dismisses the other

heading: Deaths
txt: Seishirō Itagaki, Japanese general (b. 1885)

heading: Deaths
txt: Heitarō Kimura, Japanese general (b. 1888)

heading: Deaths
txt: Iwane Matsui, Japanese general (b. 1878)

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Tupolev Tu-95
entities.description:
The Tupolev Tu-95 is a large, four-engine turboprop-powered strategic bomber and missile platform. First flown in 1952, the Tu-95 entered service with the Long-Range Aviation of the Soviet Air Forces in 1956 and is expected to serve the Russian Aerospace Forces until at least 2040.
A development of the bomber for maritime patrol is designated Tu-142, while a passenger airliner derivative was calle

entities.title: Tupolev Tu-104
entities.description: The Tupolev Tu-104 was a twinjet medium-range narrow-body turbojet-powered Soviet airliner. It was the second to enter regular service, behind the British de Havilland Comet, and was the only jetliner operating in the world from 1956 to 1958, when the British jetliner was grounded due to safety concerns.

txt: Billy Barty, American actor (b. 1924)

entities.title: Billy Barty
entities.description: Billy Barty was an American actor and activist. In adult life, he stood 3 ft 9 in (1.14 m) tall, due to cartilage–hair hypoplasia dwarfism, and because of his short stature, he was often cast in movies opposite taller performers for comic effect. He specialized in outspoken or wisecracking characters. During the 1950s, he became a television actor, appearing regularly in the Spike Jones ensemble.
